election_record.label: Vermont 1811 Governor

overview.note: The Official Canvass tally lists Jonas Galusha with a total of 13,799 votes but the sum of totals per county is 13,802.
The Vermont Republican (Windsor, VT) reports 13,792 votes for Jonas Galusha.

The Northern Centinel (Burlington, VT), October 17, reports 13,828 votes for Jonas Galusha and 11,214 votes for Martin Chittenden; however, the sum of totals per county is 13,796 for Jonas Galusha and 11,512 votes for Martin Chittenden.

The Sun (Baltimore, MD), The Green-Mountain Farmer (Bennington, VT), October 21, and The Republican (Plattsburgh, NY), November 8, report 13,828 votes for Jonas Galusha and 11,214 votes for Martin Chittenden.

The Northern Star (Danville), September 7: "So far as we have learnt, the representation, on the ground of principle, stands just about the same it did last year, notwithstanding we have had the shadow of Washington, to oppose us in the great organization of the federal phalanx to promote the circulation of the self-styled Washingtonian--We have heard too of a Pope in Rome, and of a Mahomet in Meccea, united against the Christian religion--But there is yet a God in Israel."

The Northern Star (Danville), September 21: "The federalists have not gained a single branch of the government, notwithstanding their whole forces were marshalled for months before the election, and they attended the polls with the promptitude of minute men. It was this secret organization and promptitude on the one side, and irregular remisness on the other, which varied the returns of votes any from what they were last year. Considering themselves secure, without even their usual exertions, many of the republican freemen did not attend the polls. We are credibly informed that between 30 and 40 republican votes in this town were thus lost--and that in Newbury, a similar neglect on the part of the republicans, more than twenty of whom tarried at home on the day of election, produced the choice of a federal candidate, after repeated attempts, by the enormous majority of two votes! But let the fears of the 'Green-Mountain Boys' be once alarmed--let them even suspect that federalism may possibly become triumphant, with her gag-laws, religious intolerance and 'nobles in a hole'--the whole republican phalanx of the state would move in concert, as did the federal at the late election, and would bear down all opposition with a 'strong and mighty hand'--more powerful than ever has been heretofore witnessed. The fact is, that republican principle as actually gained in this state during the past year; but having no fears to arouse them to action, too many republicans have neglected the all important duty of exercising their rights as freemen."

The Pittsfield Sun (Pittsfield, MA): "VERMONT ELECTION. Extract of a letter to the Editor, dated Bennington, Sept 15, 1811. DEAR SIR--I have the pleasure to inform you, that Federalism is again fairly distanced to Vermont. The opposition here have been perfectly organized, and industriously at work for three months, while the Republicans, thinking all was well, were attending to other concerns. The federal plan, 'to be silent in republican towns--active in federal towns'--was thoroughly tried, but has happily failed. It was a great object of New-England modern federalism to place Vermont in the federal ranks, as a defence for Canada--this accounts for the immense anxiety on the occasion. Federalism here is governed by two Juntos--the Essex Junto take the eastern, and the Canada Junto the western district. They spare no pains or money. If Vermont could be so organized as to make common cause with Canada, in the approaching contest, much service would be done the mother country ... The federal triumph in Vermont, you will see, is an English victory--'fairly beaten--in full retreat.' I congratulate you, sincerely, on this further confirmation of republican patriotism."

sub_unit.name: Jefferson
sub_unit.note: The History of Washington County in the Vermont Gazeteer: "Washington County was incorporated Nov. 1, 1810, by act of the Legislature, and organized Dec. 1, 1811, ... and was called Jefferson County until 1814, when, the Federal party coming into power, it was changed to Washington."

election_record.reference: A correct List of Votes for Governor, given by the Freemen of each town in Vermont on the 1st Tuesday of September, 1811--Sorted and counted by the Canvassing Committee. Office of the Governor. 1811.
Hemenway, Abby Maria. The History of Washington County in the Vermont Historical Gazeteer. Montpelier, VT: Vermont Watchman and State Journal Press, 1882.
